inlineContent.text: This tutorial will demonstrate how to integrate the SDK functionality into your application.
The main point of interest is

struct. You will have to configure an instance of this struct and keep it for the lifecycle of your application. Let’s have a look how we can configure it, how it communicates with the integrating code and what functionality it exposes.
Let’s have a look how the configuration is defined and how to instantiate the
First let’s’ have a look at the initializer. As you can see, we will need the
and the
and optionally
(this will be provided to you by ti&m, if not please leave it out), and a set of callbacks (will be described in the
Let’s start with the
- this is something that configures the SDK on the lowest level, setting the
for communication and some optional features like certificates for pinning (if needed) or custom headers (also optional)

All information needed to instantiate the configuration struct, except polling interval which you can define to your liking (please use the interval greater than 5 seconds), will be delivered to you by ti&m.
The next thing we need is
instance. The only required value when creating an instance, is the scan mode (
) that you want to use, for the rest it’s possible to just use the default values.
The
is very important, it decides if the SDK will try scanning the EMRTD (using NFC). It is recommended that you use

- in this mode the SDK will ask the user if their document has a chip sympol on it, and depending on what the user responds the flow will be set to either try to scan it or not. If you want to force the ERMTD scan you can use the
mode. If you don’t want EMRTD scan, use the
in which case the hologram will be scanned. All of this is also a subject of your tenant configuration.
Study the documentation of each property of
to learn what is possible and how to customise your preferences.
The
communicates with the integrating code using two methods:
protocol and a set of callbacks that can be defined after initialization. Depending on how much control you need, you can only implement the
or the delegate and the callbacks.
Implement the
protocol to be notified of the activities that the SDK is performing.
Optionally, if you require higher level of control, you may want to implement these callbacks.
There are some additional steps that need to be taken before a minimal example can be presented.
First, a theme needs to be selected. IDCheckUILib comes with a default theme which you can use.
More details on theming is provided in one of the
tutorial.
Some functionality, for example logging, is optional. Let’s have a look at what is possible.
To be able to receive the logs from inside the SDK, you may want to provide a logger object. To do this, you assign a static property on the
object.
The
will simply print the SDK logs to the console. You can replace the default implementation with your own that does specific things that you require.
Without this step you will not see any logs from the
SDK.
Finally, the entry point to the SDK is
Make sure the
is set before you call this method, as the SDK will subsequently invoke its delegate methods to communicate the need of presenting its view controllers.
The simples example consists of instantiating
and showing it to the user. The
is written in
UIKit
and so you manage the view hierarchy with subclasses of
. The SDK informs you that a view controller needs to be shown with its
method.
You may use this sample implementation as a starting point in your integration.
uses
presentingViewController
internally to present some modal phases during it’s flows, therefore it’s important that you don’t present the main
controller modally and instead push it on the
UINavigationController
stack.
To publish your app in the App Store, make sure you provide the correct app privacy details as described in the

. You can provide the details in App Store Connect by selecting “App Privacy” in the sidebar of your app. All data collected is used exclusively for the functionality of the app and is linked to the identity of the user, but no data is used for tracking purposes. The SDK itself collects the following data:
Contact Info: Name, Email Address, Phone Number, Physical Address
Location: Precise Location
Sensitive Info
User Content: Photos and Videos
Identifiers: User ID
Diagnostics: Crash Data

abstract.text: Learn how to customize the SDK UI experience.
The highlights of the
version are the new step indicator which shows the progress of the process on each screen and the unified top bar functionality.
IDCheckUIPreferences
IDCheckUILib is an UI layer on top of the IDCheckLib that simplifies it’s integration into your project.
We need to make sure you have everything to start.
Theming was fully rewritten, so new themes will need to implement the new theming protocol. Good news is the changes on the integrating application should be minimal.
This tutorial will demonstrate how to integrate the SDK functionality into your application.
To successfuly integrate the SDK, the integrating iOS application will need specific permissions and entitlements.

content: // Do any additional setup after loading the view.
IDCheckUI.theme = IDCheckTheme.default //<- if you want to use the default theme, otherwise see the Theming tutorial
// Here you can present a loading indicator to the user
// Here you can hide the loading indicator
// The IDCheckUI will inform you that it needs to show this view controller
// The IDCheckUI will inform you that the presented view controller will be dismissed
// The IDCheckUI will inform you of the process completion and the result - true if successful, false if failed
// Here the IDCheckUI will inform you that the processing is taking place and you may want to present an intermediate waiting view

This method is invoked when the SDK presents a view controller. During the process the SDK will show different view controllers for different functionality, for example document scan, NFC read or liveness. This delegate method let’s the integrating code react when this happens.

Theming was improved to allow for more flexibility. This release is compatible with 2.1 and 2.2 so you don’t really need to do anything, but we think it’s worth the time to understand what improvements were made.

content: /// Use this initializer to set up an instance of IDCheckUI
///   - processID: processID as string, this is something you will get from ti&m or leave it empty for the SDK to figure it out on it's own
///   - endStateActionSuccess: this callback is invoked when the process succeeds
///   - endStateActionPending: this callback is invoked when the process is processing
///   - endStateActionFailed: this callback is invoked when the process failed
///   - endStateActionError: this callback is invoked when the process encounters an error

abstract.text: Learn how to customize the SDK UI experience.
The highlights of the
version are the new step indicator which shows the progress of the process on each screen and the unified top bar functionality.

Theming was improved to allow for more flexibility. This release is compatible with 2.1 and 2.2 so you don’t really need to do anything, but we think it’s worth the time to understand what improvements were made.
This delegate protocol is the main way of communication between the IDCheckUI and the integrating code

content: /// This struct is used to configure specific options of different steps used throughout IDCheckUI

///   - address: default to `nil`. By setting this property, the `IDCheckUIAddressVerificationViewController` gets prefilled with it address and the AddressMap doesn't get shown. This is useful in multiple situations, e.g. when the user is recovering from an interrupted session where they already specified the address.
///   - preferredScanMode: the IDCheckUIPreferredScanMode best suited for the use case
///   - documentVerificationPreferences: default to `IDCheckUIDocumentVerificationPreferences()`, used to define options specific to the document verification task
///   - emrtdVerificationPreferences: default to `IDCheckUIEMRTDVerificationPreferences()`, used to define options specific to the EMRTD verification task
///   - selfieVerificationPreferences: default to `IDCheckUISelfieVerificationPreferences()` used to define options specific to the selfie verification task
///   - allowTaskSkipping: default true - sometimes you may want to skip some tasks that may not be mandatory for your process, for example the NFC readout can be skipped in some scenarios
///   - useIntro: default true - you may want to skip the intro, for example if the user is coming back from a previously interrupted session
///   - defaultIntroDocumentTypes: this variable is used to define which intro screens are shown in case it's not possible to get this information from the config call
///   - showStepIndicator: default to true, with this flag you can disable or enable the step indicator on every screen
/// A delegate is the main way the IDCheckUI communicates with the integrating code
/// Callback for when the process succeeded, this callback is executed before the `IDCheckUIDelegate` method
/// Callback for when the SDK is processing e.g. documents or selfie is being verified etc. This callback is executed before the `IDCheckUIDelegate` method
/// Callback for when the process has failed
/// Callback for when the SDK encountered an error, you may want to show a generic error message here

abstract.text: IDCheckUILib - UI module for IDCheckLib

Defines which scan mode will be used when scanning the document. The .full mode scans the document, together with hologram etc. The .preNFC mode additionally reads the NFC chip of the document. The .ask mode will display a view to the user asking them if their document has the chip, and continue with the best scanning mode depending on the user choice.
Learn how to customize the SDK UI experience.

Theming was improved to allow for more flexibility. This release is compatible with 2.1 and 2.2 so you don’t really need to do anything, but we think it’s worth the time to understand what improvements were made.

content: /// Creates an instance configured with all required parameters
///   - apiURL: URL of the API, together with the version e.g. `https://id-check-int.ti8m.ch/delegate/id-check-process-adapter/v5`
///   - socketScanURL: URL of the document scan socket, together with the version and socket release e.g. `wss://id-check-int.ti8m.ch/delegate/id-check-scan/v2/documents/scan/socket/?rel=albis`
///   - socketEMRTDURL: URL of the NFC scan socket, together with the version and socket release e.g. `wss://id-check-int.ti8m.ch/delegate/id-check-emrtd/v1/documents/emrtd/socket/?rel=albis`
///   - socketLivenessURL: (Added in version 6.0) URL of the liveness scan socket e.g.
///   - loggingURL: your logging URL, can be skipped with an empty string
///   - tenantID: your tennant ID as String
///   - pollingInterval: a desired polling interval in milliseconds as Int
///   - certificates: an array of certificates for connecting to the API (pinning), if needed (these are the names of .cer files included in the integrating application bundle, without extension)
///   - customHeaders: a dictionary of additional headers used for connecting to the API, if needed
/// This delegate protocol is the main way of communication between the IDCheckUI and the integrating code
/// This method is invoked when the SDK is processing. The integrating code gets a chance to improve the UI experiece by presenting a loading indicator to the user.
/// This method is invoked when the SDK finishes processing, if a loading indicator was presented by the integrating code, now is the time to dismiss it.

/// This method is invoked when the SDK presents a view controller. During the process the SDK will show different view controllers for different functionality, for example document scan, NFC read or liveness. This delegate method lets the integrating code react when this happens.
/// This method is invoked when the SDK dismisses a view controller, and gives the integrating code a chance to react when this happens.
/// This method is invoked when the SDK completes the process. The process can finish successfully or fail, this is communicated by the result parameter.
/// This method is invoked when the SDK is processing, giving the integrating code a chance to present a waiting screen if needed.
